column4: I just installed Ubuntu and I want to set up a way to make my Windows 7 partition bootable with a virtual machine and also avaiable to boot into from start up.  Any ideas? :)
well, it's bootable from startup via grub, so no problems there
for inside a virtual machine, use kvm, or vmware and specify the disk image as your windows partition, and it will boot
it's that simple
VMware only give me the option of picking ISOs for disk images... =/
that's install media
use kvm then, it works fine here, I use it all the time
on the KVM install page, it says its assuming I am using a server with no X.  How will the fact that I am NOT using a server and DO have X installed change this install guide?
nothing
it's easier with X as you can use the libvirt gui
I got KVM installed with the GUI, but its still not giving me an option to open a already installed OS file system.  I got using local media and through a network.
that's install media options, you don't want to do an install
create a disk image, and instead of using a disk image, select your partition on the real physical disk
you won't need to install then, just power on the VM
is this making a copy of the WIndows install?
no
you already have windows installed on a partition, tell the kvm machine to use that partition instead of a virual disk, and then power on the vm, it will boot from the physical partition
you don't need to create
you've got the install you want to use on the partition
Sorry if I am being completely oblivious, I am not seeing how to tell KVM to use the NTFS partition.  I am using the GUI for KVM made by Canocial
it asks you to make a file for the file system for the vm, point it at the partition
